bibl.title: In the Matter of the Application of Elsie Miller Dickinson for a Writ of Habeas Corpus. Petition
bibl.note: Our transcription is based on a digital image of the original.

org.orgName: Western District Court of Washington, Northern Division

div1.p: IN THE DISTRICT COURT OF THE UNITED STATES, FOR THE WESTERN DISTRICT OF WASHINGTON, NORTHERN DIVISION.
IN THE MATTER OF THE APPLICATION OF ELSIE MILLER DICKINSON, ALIAS ELSIE MILLER for a WRIT OF HABEAS CORPUS
NO. 2965 PETITION FOR A WRIT OF HABEAS CORPUS.
To The Honorable The Judges of the above entitled court:
Now comes Elsie Miller Dickinson, alias Elsie Miller, and represents and shows unto Your Honors as follows:
I.

That she is a citizen of the United States of America, over the age of twenty-one years, a resident and citizen of the State of Washington and the district and division of the above entitled court above specified; that your petitioner is a native of the Empire of Russia, and came to the United States of America in the year 1907 where your petitioner has since resided.
II.

That your petitioner intermarried with one Fred Dickinson at Seattle, in the State of Washington, on the 11th day of November, 1914, and that thereafter at all times has been, and still is, the lawful wife of the said Fred Dickinson; that at the time of said intermarriage of your petitioner and said Fred Dickinson in the said City of Seattle, State of Washington, in the United States of America, the said Fred Dickinson was a natural born citizen of the United States having been born at the town of Brandon, in the State of Minnesota, in the United States of America, and never having 1
renounced the allegiance acquired by such birth.
III.

That on or about the 13th day of October, 1914, your petitioner was taken into custody at Skagway, Alaska, by one Albert H. Joy, Immigration Inspector of the United States, upon a warrant issued by one J. B. Densmore, Acting Secretary of Labor of the United States, charging your petitioner with being an alien in the United States of America and with being a prostitute, and that she entered the United States for the purpose of prostitution. That thereafter, a hearing was had before the said Albert H. Joy on the 15th day of October, 1914, and said cause was transferred for further hearing to Seattle, Washington, where a hearing upon such charge was held before Thos. W. Lynch, Examining Inspector, and thereafter your petitioner was taken into custody and is now in custody of Henry M. White, Commissioner of Immigration, under and by virtue of a warrant issued by the Secretary of the Department of Labor of the United States of America directing that your petitioner be deported from the United States of America and transported to the Empire of Russia for the reason as stated in said warrant, that your petitioner is an alien in the United States and has been found practicing prostitution in the United States of America.
IV.

Your petitioner further avers that she is restrained of her liberty by the said Henry M. White, as such Commissioner of Immigration, under a claim that she is subject to deportation for a violation of the laws of the United States in that being an alien she was found practicing prostitution in the United States of America.
V.

Your petitioner further avers that she is held in custody under and by virtue of a claim that she has violated the laws of the United States of America, and is being held in such custody within the district and division aforesaid.
VI.

Your petitioner further avers that she is unable to attach hereto a copy of the process under which she is held in custody and restrained of her liberty for the reason that she has no such copy in her possession, and for the reason that she has not been furnished with such copy.
VII.

Your petitioner, however, avers that she is being now restrained of her liberty and held in the custody of Henry M. White, Commissioner of Immigration, under a pretense of a law of the United States of America.
VIII.

Your petitioner further avers that at the said hearing before the said Thos. W. Lynch, Examining Inspector, it appeared conclusively and without contradiction that your petitioner at all times since her said marriage with the said Fred Dickinson has been a resident of the United States of America and a citizen thereof, and that the said warrant of the Secretary of Labor is invalid and of now force and effect in law for the reason that your petitioner is not an alien.
IX.

Your petitioner now complains that she is unlawfully restrained of her liberty by the said Henry M. White under the pretense that she has violated a law of the United States of America, which pretense and claim is unfounded in fact and is to the said Henry M. White and to the Secretary of Labor of the United States well known.
X.

Your petitioner further avers that in her confinement by the said Henry M. White her rights as an American citizen are infringed and she is deprived of her liberty without any warrant of law and that such restraint is illegal and invalid.
XI.

Your petitioner further avers that in the hearing before the officers of the Immigration Service of the United States, she was denied the right to cross-examine witnesses, to meet the witnesses face to face, and that your petitioner in such hearing before the officers of the Immigration Service of the United States was denied a fair and impartial hearing, and that there was no testimony taken before the said Albert H. Joy or Thos. W. Lynch tending to show, or which did show, that your petitioner was at any time subsequent to her said intermarriage with said Fred Dickinson an alien to the United States of America.

WHEREFORE your petitioner prays that she may be allowed the writ of right, a Writ of Habeas Corpus to The Honorable Henry M. White, Commissioner of Immigration, directing, commanding and requiring the said Henry M. White to produce before Your Honor at a time and place to be specified, the body of your petitioner, together with the cause alleged for her detention by the said Henry M. White, and that she further be awarded a Writ of Certiorari to The Honorable Henry M. White, Commissioner of Immigration, commanding and requiring the said Commissioner to certify unto this court all and singular the proceedings had before siad Albert H. Joy and Thos. W. Lynch, as such Immigration Inspectors, respecting the matter of the deportation of your petitioner, and that upon the return to such Writ of Habeas Corpus and the return to such Writ of Certiorari such order be made there by Your Honors as upon 4
due consideration is consonant with law under and pursuant to the Constitution of the United States of America and as in duty bound your petitioner will ever pray.
div1.ab:
ELSIE MILLER DICKINSON,
Petitioner,
VANDERVEER & CUMMINGS,
Attorneys for Petitioner.
div1.p: WESTERN DISTRICT OF WASHINGTON: NORTHERN DIVISION : SS

ELSIE MILLER DICKINSON, being first and duly sworn, upon oath deposes and says: That she is the petitioner named in and by whom the foregoing petition is subscribed; that she knows the contents thereof; and that all the matters and things in said petition set forth are true.
Subscribed and sworn to before me this 18th day of February, A. D. 1915.
div1.ab:
H. W. C. Billingsley
Notary Public in and for the State of Washington, residing at Seattle.
div1.p: ORIGINAL COPY
Cause No. 2965
IN THE DISTRICT COURT OF THE UNITED STATES FOR THE WESTERN DISTRICT OF WASHINGTON NORTHERN DIVISION
IN THE MATTER OF THE APPLICATION OF ELSIE Plaintiff vs. MILLER DICKINSON ETC. FOR WRIT OF HABEAS CORPUS. Defendant
PETITION FOR A WRIT OF HABEAS CORPUS.
McBURNEY & CUMMINGS VANDERVEER & CUMMINGS Solicitors and Counsel for PETITIONER. BOSTON BLOCK SEATTLE - WASHINGTON RAINIER PRINTING COMPANY, INC.
2x
FILED IN THE U. S. District Court, Western Dist. of Washington, NORTHERN DIVISION FEB 18 1915
div1.ab:
FRANK L. CROSBY, Clerk,
By EML Deputy
